Introduction

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) encompasses a spectrum of conditions involving abnormal development of the hip joint in infants and children.  It arises from abnormal contact between the acetabulum and proximal femur, disrupting development and resulting in instability of the hip joint.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Proper hip joint development requires normal contact between the acetabulum and femoral head, which facilitates reciprocal induction (ie, the 2 interacting tissues are each inducers for the other's development).  Disruption of this contact impedes normal hip development, resulting in a shallow hip socket and inadequate support of the femoral head.  Risk factors include both mechanical forces and genetic factors.



Mechanical forces



  • Before birth:  Near the end of pregnancy, the femur's normal rapid growth results in the acetabular roof having limited coverage of the femoral head.  Therefore, normal hip joint contact is easily disrupted by any mechanical force (eg, adduction) that directs the femoral head away from the central portion of the acetabulum.  A common risk factor is breech positioning, which can accentuate this process by limiting fetal movement.
  • After birth:  External mechanical forces that put the hips in adduction and extension (eg, improper swaddling (
    figure 1
    ) and narrow-base car seats (
    figure 2
    )) can also inhibit normal hip joint development by disrupting normal joint contact.


Genetic factors



  • Female sex:  2-3 times more common in females
  • Family history:  First- and second-degree relatives of those with DDH are at higher risk.

Clinical presentation



Presentation varies depending on age and severity.  Possible findings include:

Toddlers and older children/adolescents



  • Leg-length discrepancy with limping or Trendelenburg gait (

    )
  • Excessive lordosis
  • Prominent greater trochanter
  • Activity-related pain in the hip and groin
  • Premature joint degeneration/arthritis due to accelerated wear on the cartilage

Diagnostic evaluation



DDH is diagnosed by physical examination showing hip instability, asymmetry between the hips, and/or limited hip abduction.  Diagnostic imaging may help confirm the diagnosis in at-risk infants who have normal or equivocal examination findings.



  • Age â‰¤4 months:  Hip ultrasound is preferred due to ability to visualize cartilaginous structures (the femoral head and acetabulum are not sufficiently ossified to visualize on radiographs prior to age 4 months).  Hip ultrasound at age <6 weeks may be difficult to interpret due to immature acetabular development and expected joint capsular laxity in the first few weeks of life.
  • Age >4 months:  Hip radiographs help assess joint alignment given that the femoral head and acetabulum are now ossified and can be visualized.

Management



The goal of treatment is to provide an optimal environment for the femoral head and acetabulum to develop by obtaining and maintaining proper alignment.  The methods utilized depend on patient age.



  • Age <6 months:  If age <1 month, mild laxity may be monitored for spontaneous resolution.  For those with more severe or persistent findings, a Pavlik harness (
    figure 6
    ) (a splint maintaining the hip in a flexed, abducted position to maintain proper alignment) is recommended.
  • Age >6 months or failed abduction splint:  Closed or open reduction of the hip joint.

Prevention



The risk for DDH may be reduced by limiting external mechanical forces that put the hips in adduction and extension (eg, improper swaddling, narrow-base car seats).

Prognosis



Early detection and treatment of DDH generally yield favorable outcomes, often leading to normal hip joint development.  Untreated DDH can result in persistent hip instability, gait abnormalities, and early-onset osteoarthritis in adolescence.

Summary



Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) (
